intro: Thymus serpyllum var. chamaedrys, commonly known as creeping thyme, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Europe and western Asia. It features small, fragrant leaves that are often used in culinary and medicinal applications. The plant produces pink or white flowers in early summer, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its dense growth habit makes it an excellent ground cover plant in gardens and rocky areas. Botanically, it belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic essential oils.
